LANDS BELONGING TO URBAN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY
asked the Minister of Urban Development, Construction and Housing:
(i) whether the extents of lands belonging to the Urban Development Authority within the City of Colombo have been identified, separately in respect of each land;
(ii) the lands expected to be used for investment projects out of the lands concerned ; and
(iii) the investment projects expected to be undertaken in each of the lands, separately?
( , ) ( - , ) (The Hon. Anura Karunathilaka - Minister of Urban Development, Construction and Housing) .

: : COMPANIES INCORPORATED BY DEPARTMENT OF THE
() , ? asked the Minister of Trade, Commerce, Food Security and Co-operative Development:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) the name of the present Registrar of Companies; (ii) the names of individuals who have held the post of Registrar of Companies from 2015 to 2024; (iii) the total number of companies incorporated by the Department of the Registrar of Companies to date; (iv) the number of companies incorporated in each of the following years, 2010, 2015, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024 and 2025 up-to-date, separately; (v) the average time taken to incorporate a company; (vi) the total revenue earned by the Department from incorporation of companies as per (iii) above; (vii) the number of active companies currently operating as per (iii) above; and (viii) whether the Department of the Registrar of Companies has been fully automated?
(, , ) ( - , , ) (The Hon. Wasantha Samarasinghe - Minister of Trade, Commerce, Food Security and Co-operative Development) .

PROPOSED "PORT CITY " PROJECT IN GALLE PORT AREA:
) (The Hon. Ajith Gihan on behalf of the Hon. (Dr.)
() , ? asked the Minister of Transport, Highways, Ports and Civil Aviation:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) the benefits expected from the "Port City" Project proposed to be implemented in the area associated with the Galle Port; (ii) whether a feasibility study has been conducted in relation to the impacts caused to the environment by that project; (iii) the changes that have been made relating to the project as a result of the public outcry raised previously; and (iv) whether the impact of this proposed project on the life of the community has been taken into consideration?
NATIONAL YOUTH CORPS TRAINING CENTRE, KINNIYA:
) (The Hon. Gayantha Karunathilleka on behalf of the Hon.
() , ? asked the Minister of Youth Affairs and Sports:
(i) the number of National Youth Corps training centres established in each of the Divisional Secretaries' Divisions of the Trincomalee District, separately;
(ii) whether he is aware that the training centre that was established in Kinniya area has been closed down and relocated to another area;
(iii) the reasons for closing down the training centre concerned;
(iv) the reasons for relocating it in another area;
(v) whether there is any obstacle to reopening the training centre concerned;
(vi) if not, whether steps will be taken to reopen the training centre concerned; and
(vii) if so, the steps that have been taken in that regard?
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Sunil Kumara Gamage - Minister of Youth Affairs and Sports) * .

[.. 11.02] () ( ) ( () - ) (The Hon. Major General (Rtd.) Aruna Jayasekera - Deputy Minister of Defence) 2025 . 7 . . . .
. . . it is not only an economic and a political crisis, but also a crisis of collapsed democracy, governance and moral values. . . , . .

What has happened to our country? Hon. Chairman, the rulers made it economically bankrupt and allowed it to be infested with massives crimes. The rule of law had been completely collapsed when we came to power and even before that. The Judiciary had been badly challenged by the Executive. Suspicion, anger and mistrust grew among the communities, including in the North and the East or whatever we may call it. There was no food and medicine in hospitals. Bad policies led the State to severe corruption. The worst that could happen to a country had happened.

" - " 225 . . . ; . ; . Hon. Chairman, if these precautions have been taken, we could relax a bit. But, unfortunately, I do not see that the Government is taking this seriously. . .

However much you are tempted to put your own people - your political supporters and your cadres - into those positions, please do not think about doing that because public security is a very serious matter, as we have experienced. Sir, today, there are all these issues including the economic troubles we are going through with about 300,000 entrepreneurs suffering. Why? Because after the Easter attack, we have still not been able to stand up. We do not have the energy, the resources or anything to face another situation like this.

Hon. Deputy Chairperson, in the 2025 Budget, for defence, there has been an allocation of Rs. 434 billion, which is a 3 per cent increase from the previous year, and for public security and Parliamentary affairs, a further Rs. 175 billion has been allocated. As far as I am concerned and certainly as far as the North and the East is concerned, Madam, the police behave very much on the instructions of the military and we do not differentiate between the two. So, I would like to include that figure with defence for my analysis.

The Budget also provides for a significant salary hike for military personnel ranging from 27 per cent to 33 per cent. Why that becomes relevant, Madam, is that it shows that the Government has prioritized the defence establishment to a point where they want to enhance the defence forces. That is in a scenario where there is no war and where the war had come to an end over 16 to17 years ago, but despite that, there is that intention to enhance the sector. That is also despite the Budget deficit reaching 6.7 per cent of GDP, whilst the target set by the IMF, if I am not mistaken, is 5.2 per cent. So, none of this is helping; it is actually making things worse. Further, the Government must increase its revenue collection to 15.1 per cent of GDP to remain eligible for the next IMF tranche of a bailout package. So, all of this is increasing the burden very severely.

Now, defence, very clearly, has been prioritized over social welfare. I mean, the figures are quite staggering, Madam! Social welfare has been slashed, slashed, to Rs. 43 billion. That is, slashed by Rs. 35 billion compared to last year at a time when the most vulnerable sections of this country are struggling because of the economic crisis and the increasing prices. But, you all are slashing all the sectors which actually need to be enhanced; when the most vulnerable need to be protected and in some way strengthened, they are doing the opposite. In fact, the IMF recommendation was that social welfare must be enhanced and there was even criticism of the previous Government that there was not adequate support given to social welfare. So, this would terribly affect the very vulnerable sections, not just in the North and East - certainly, in the North and the East because if you take the GDP, the Northern Province is the last out of all the provinces - but in the entire country. So, we are right at the bottom and are affected very really by these slashes.

What is important, Madam, is that all the speakers who spoke before me spoke with regard to the need to strengthen the defence establishment because of Sri Lankas locality, because it is an island, because of drugs and various other problems that face this region. Let us take it at face value, that it has no sinister motive, that it is a genuine question of strengthening security to ensure that the whole Island is secure. But, if that is the case, how do you account for what I am going to now place on record? There is a ratio, Madam, of 1.5 soldiers to every 100 civilians. That is the ratio of Sri Lankas defence establishment - 1.5: 100. What I just told you is the ratio for the whole Island . But, if you take Mullaitivu, there is a minimum of one solider for every two civilians! If you take the military, there are 20 divisions and 16 of those divisions are based in the North and the East. So, how do you look at this security picture? I can understand you making the argument that Sri Lanka must look into its security and for that, you must strengthen the defence establishment. But, what does this mean? What are the demographies of the regions where you have placed your entire military? It is the Tamil-speaking areas, areas that we represent. What is the message you are giving? Who is the enemy? When you talk of defence, Madam, who do you consider the enemy? I can understand previous Governments doing it, but this Government itself admitted that they were all racist, but that same policy is being pursued today. Surely, that cannot be right. You came into power saying that you are going to get rid of racism. You are asking us, our party and the people who represent the North and the East, to forget about the past because you are now in power and that you will ensure that there would not be racism and hostility towards us. I am asking you, Madam, how on earth can you justify the 1:2 ratio in a place called Mullaitivu? Do you not feel that that is suffocating? Do the Tamils not get the feeling "you are the enemy"? That is what the county feels; the country feels "you are an enemy". That is what you are telling the Tamils because that is the reality.

Now, I am tired, Madam, of raising this repeatedly. Actually, there is a young gentleman who covers Parliamentary affairs and who has been good enough to cover my speeches. He made a comment. He said, Sir, I

quite appreciate how strongly you bring out the cause of your people. But, honestly, I am tired of constantly having to bring out only my peoples problems, that I cannot feel that I can contribute to the rest of the country because that is the burden you have been placing on us. In every field, we feel that we are scraping the barrel, and no other field drives through the message so strongly than the Defence Ministry and the Ministry of Public Security. Considering the way in which those under the two Ministries behave in the North and the East and the policies of not just the previous Governments, but even of this Government, we see no change. Therefore, the allocation to the Ministry of Defence alone is enough for us to oppose this Budget; that is the way we feel. And, if this Government feels that they need to change this, that they need to be genuine with regard to this system change they promised, then that must be the first thing they look at with regard to the North and the East.

The speaker who spoke before me represents the Vanni Electoral District and the poor Hon. Member tried very hard to justify the allocations for defence and to play it down. Representing the Vanni, he also represents Mullaitivu; he being a Member of the Vanni means that Mullaitivu is a part of his Electorate. He should feel ashamed that he has to justify that 1:2 ratio!
I honestly ask you, do you not feel claustrophobic? Do you not feel suffocated? Would you accept that in your areas? Would you?

And, what else does the defence establishment do? The teachers of the defence establishment are teaching in preschools. I mentioned this even during the Budget Debate. The Defence establishment employs preschool teachers. The Ministry of Education employs preschool teachers for Rs. 6,000 while the defence establishment employs them for Rs. 30,000! In an area where you have had 35 years of war and where their economy is scraping the barrel, when you are given a choice between Rs. 6,000 and Rs. 30,000 or Rs. 40,000, which section of preschools would you want to get employed in? Are you not deliberately, by keeping that difference, militarizing education in the North and the East? What is the intention then? Therefore, is it a post-war feeling that you get when you listen to these figures? So, this has to change. Madam, I am tabling* two reports. One is a report by the Citizen Fact Check on this 1:2 ratio and the other is by Adayaalam Centre for Policy Research.

If you take the entire Northern Province, Madam, that ratio is 1:10. In Mullaitivu, it is 1:2 and in Killinochchi, 1:4. But, if you take the Northern Province, overall, it is 1:10. When it comes to the entire country, it is 1.5:100. So, who is the enemy? You all should feel ashamed; the Hon. Members seated opposite should feel ashamed! If you want to get rid of racism, the first thing you should

have done is to begin to change this. Then, you would have had us believe that there is actually a chance of things happening differently. But, you have not done that; you have increased the Budgetary allocation instead. Despite the fact that we have been raising these issues at the Consultative Committee as well as on the Floor of this House, you have not done anything concrete to change that. On dividual instances - the Hon. Mano Ganesan brought up a few - we have brought this up, but you have not changed. Nothing has changed. So, this has to change, Madam. Without changing that, to simply tell us that you will get rid of racism is just hogwash; it means nothing.
Therefore, we will be calling for a Division and will be voting against the Heads of both the Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of Public Security.

( ) (The Hon. Shanakiyan Rajaputhiran Rasamanickam) Hon. Chairman, today, as we discuss the Votes of the Ministry of Defence at the Committee Stage Discussion

of the Appropriation Bill, still, there are serious issues with regard to accountability within this country. I am glad that the Hon. President is also in the House when I speak. On the accountability front - Hon. President, this is related to the Ministry of Defence as well - we still have not seen anything progressive or received any comments from the Government. Whether you all are going to continue with a domestic process or go for an international process and whether there is going to be any accountability in this country still remain a huge question. So, since you are in this House, Hon. President, I would like if you could clarify that in your speech.

( ) (The Hon. Chairman) . () ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Ramanathan Archchuna) Good afternoon, Hon. President and Hon. Prime Minister!

Hon. Chairman, thank you for giving me this opportunity. As the Hon. Nalin Bandara Jayamaha mentioned, we are from the North and we do not want another division in this country. We want to live together with the Sinhalese people as friends and as a core part of this country. So, on this occasion, we would like to hear from the Hon. President that we would get a new Constitution and equal rights.

At 6.44 p.m., the Chairman left the Chair to report Progress. Committee report Progress; to sit again on Saturday, 01st March, 2025.
( ) (The Hon. Bimal Rathnayake) . Parliamentary Business Committee . 158 . .
And it being past 6.30 p.m., THE HON. SPEAKER adjourned Parliament without Question put.
Parliament adjourned accordingly at 6.45 p.m until 9.30 a.m. on Saturday, 01st March, 2025, pursuant to the Resolution of Parliament of 21st February, 2025.
